results.title: Absolutely fabulous
results.creator_credit: Bob Spiers, Jon Plowman and BBC
results.brief_description: Absolutely fabulous is one of the most successful British comedy shows; an hilarious situation comedy that plays with elements of the absurd and high camp. Edwina (Jennifer Saunders) is a baby-boomer mother, fashion victim extraordinaire. Her best friend is the cocaine-snorting nymphomaniac Patsy (Joanna Lumley). Part of the show’s success comes from its reversal of roles. It is the practical long-suffering Saffie, Edwina’s daughter, who sweeps up after her mother, and the in-your-face portrayal of drug-taking, sex-loving, materialistic women who are spoilt, selfish, vacuous but undeniably good fun. Always colourful, often brilliant, “Absolutely fabulous” confirmed Saunders and co-writer Dawn French as two of the best comedians of their generation.

results.title: Absolute power
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Karen Spiegel, Malpaso Company and Castle Rock Entertainment
results.brief_description: Absolute Power is a political thriller about a retiring thief who witnesses a murder - by the President of the United States. Fearing that he will be blamed, the thief plans to flee the country - after making amends with his estranged daughter - but decides instead to stay and fight the hypocrisy. Masterfully directed (and starring) Clint Eastwood, this paranoid conspiracy crime story bristles with suspense and features an all impressive cast that includes Gene Hackman, Ed Harris, Laura Linney, Scott Glenn, Dennis Haysbert, E.G. Marshall and Judy Davis.

results.title: Absolute beginners
results.creator_credit: Julien Temple, Chris Brown, Stephen Woolley, Goldcrest Films, Virgin Films and Palace Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in London in 1958, this unconventional rock musical is based on Colin MacInnes’ cult novel about emerging teen culture and racial tension in London circa 1958. Told from the perspective of eighteen year old Colin, a budding photographer and jazz fan, the film takes the viewer on a nostalgic, stylised trip into the social and cultural milieu of Soho and Notting Hill. The story revolves around Colin’s thwarted relationship with Suzette, who works for a chic couturier in Mayfair. Inspired by the artifice of Classic Hollywood musicals, director Julien Temple, who had previously made a name filming rock videos, gives this genre a visually inventive and energetic twist. The film features an impressive one-take opening sequence a la ‘Touch of Evil’, a string of dazzling production numbers set to a jazz inflected score by Gil Evans and a cast that includes David Bowie, Sade, Ray Davies, James Fox and Patsy Kensit.

results.title: Abraham Valley = Vale Abraao
results.creator_credit: Manuel de Oliveira, Paolo Branco, Light Night Production, Gemini Films and Madragoa Filmes
results.brief_description: ‘Abraham Valley’ is directed by Portuguese filmmaker, Manoel de Oliveira, who at 94, is a senior and prolific figure in contemporary world cinema. This film is adapted from a novel by Agustina Bessa-Luis that in turn adapts “Madame Bovary’ for a Portuguese audience. Running at 3 hours, ‘Abraham Valley’ spans the life of a woman, Ema Cardeano Paiva (played by Leonor Silveira), who is searching for fulfillment. At a young age, she is shown to possess powerful beauty that commands the attention of older men and causes car accidents in the local village. Living with her father and a handful of servants in a large mansion, her mother having passed away, Ema assumes the role of the matriarch or feminine ideal from an early age. She enters into a loveless marriage with the tepid, wealthy Carlo Paiva (played by Luis Miguel Cintra), and gives birth to two daughters, though continues to seek the interest of other men and to enter a series of affairs. ‘Abraham Valley’ presents a portrait of woman as refined and elegant, intelligent and sensitive, but as one who above all desires to be desired, as though this were a form of self-validation. Oliveria’s films generally transpire within lavish, refined and aristocratic surroundings and are ‘literary’ and ‘theatrical’ in the best sense: by being replete with detail in the dialogue and voice-over, they give texture and depth to the characters and their situations. This literary emphasis is one aspect of Oliveria’s style, which is detached, elegant, poetic and unsentimental. And so he can just as easily switch from glorious personal reverie to accidental death and capture all the emotion and irony of the latter in an inert object in the frame that his camera happens to fall upon. In Portuguese with English subtitles.

results.title: Abraham Lincoln. - 2nd edition.
results.creator_credit: Kathy Tallon, Scott Craig and Scott Craig Productions
results.brief_description: Beginning with the statement that Lincoln became the “last victim of the Civil War”, when he was assassinated, the film traces his life from humble beginnings in a log cabin, an axe wielding woodsman and also voracious reader as a youth, to candidate to the State Assembly at twenty-three in 1832. However, the film gives no hint of criticism of Lincoln, who spoke “with courage and conviction for all people”, and no analysis of the causes of events or action is attempted.

results.title: Abraham Lincoln
results.creator_credit: Paul Nickell, Dorothy Mathews, Donald Davis and Westinghouse Studio One
results.brief_description: Television adaptation of English playwright and poet John Drinkwater’s play “Abraham Lincoln” which features a cameo role towards the end of the program by James Dean as a reluctant Union soldier sentenced to death for sleeping on guard duty. This live television drama documents a part of Lincoln’s life from his nomination for presidency through to his attendance at Ford’s Theater where his eventual assassination took place. Stars Robert Pastene as Abraham Lincoln and Judith Evelyn as Mary Lincoln. Also includes classic Westinghouse ad-breaks at intervals throughout the program. NB: Picture quality and sound is variable.
